Award.AwardTitle: Geopolymerization of Mine Tailings for Sustainable Development

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The major objective of this research effort is to study the stabilization of mine tailings through geopolymerization so that they can be used as construction material in large scale and in a cost-effective way. The research will use an innovative multi-scale and multi-disciplinary approach and consist of (a) macro-scale study of the mechanical and environmental properties of mine tailings after geopolymerization; (b) investigation of the micro/nano-scale structures and interactions of mine tailings after geopolymerization; and (c) discrete element method simulations to investigate how the micro/nano-scale characteristics affect the macro-scale behavior.

This project will help promote the utilization of mine tailings as construction material and reduce the disposal of mine tailings, saving the land required for the disposal impoundments and the related high monetary, environmental and ecological costs, reducing the demand for virgin materials that would need quarrying, and decreasing the use of energy-intensive ordinary Portland cement. So it will contribute to sustainable development and have major economical, environmental and societal impacts. By integrating the research results into graduate, undergraduate, and online courses, this project will broaden awareness and knowledge of civil engineering students on sustainable development, a topic increasingly emphasized in Civil Engineering. Combining the research with the on campus Summer Engineering Academy and K-12 mentoring programs will introduce K-12 students from diverse backgrounds to the field of sustainable development. This research will also broaden participation of underrepresented groups in a significant way, by recruiting and mentoring graduate and undergraduate assistants from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Significant amounts of materials are used in the construction industry and there is a shortage of raw materials in many parts of the United States. On the other hand, the mining industry generates a large amount of mine tailings every years and the disposal of mine tailings occupies large area of land and leads to high monetary, environmental and ecological costs. If mine tailings can be recycled and used as construction material, it will be a great contribution to sustainable development.

This project, for the first time, systematically investigated the feasibility of utilizing mine tailings as construction materials such as bricks and road construction material based on a relatively new technology called geopolymerization. Geopolymerization is the chemical reaction of a solid aluminosilicate with a highly concentrated aqueous alkali hydroxide or silicate solution at ambient or slightly higher temperatures to form a cement-like material called geopolymer. Geopolymer not only provides performance comparable to conventional Portland cement in many applications, but also has additional advantages, including rapid development of mechanical strength, acid resistance, immobilization of toxic and hazardous materials, and significantly reduced energy usage and greenhouse emissions. Since mine tailings contain high silica and alumina components, potentially they can be geopolymerized and used as construction material.

In the aspect of Intellectual Merit, the project took an innovative multi-scale and multi-disciplinary approach to investigate the underlying mechanism for geopolymerization of mine tailings. Specifically, the research systematically studied the chemical reactivity of mine tailings from different mine sites, the effect of different factors on the geopolymerization of mine tailings, the pretreatment of mine tailings to enhance their geopolymerization, and the use of mine tailings together with other types of wastes such as fly ash, slag, cement kiln dust and aluminum sludge in order to enhance the physical and mechanical properties and durability of mine tailings-based geopolymer products. The research has led to enhanced understanding of the underlying mechanism for geopolymerization of mine tailings by innovatively linking the micro/nano-scale characteristics and the macro-scale behavior.

This project also has great Broader Impacts related to economics, environment and society. The project has successfully developed the method for utilizing mine tailings as construction materials such as bricks and road construction material through geopolymerization. It will promote the recycling and utilization of mine tailings as construction material and decrease the disposal of mine tailings, saving the land required for the disposal impoundments and the related high monetary, environmental and ecological costs, reducing the demand for virgin materials that would need quarrying, and decreasing the use of energy-intensive conventional Portland cement. Therefore, this project will contribute to sustainable development and have major economical, environmental and societal impacts.
